qas.question: When was the Hauppauge 1212 Personal Video Recorder introduced?
How does the Personal Video Recorder store content?

answers.text: in MPEG-2 format in a .ts file or in a Blu-ray compatible format .m2ts file

qas.question: Recent systems can record a broadcast HD program in what format?

answers.text: 'as broadcast' format or transcode to a format more compatible with Blu-ray

qas.question: What uncompressed storage option was introduced in 2008?
When was the Hauppauge 1212 NonPersonal Video Recorder introduced?

plausible_answers.text: MPEG-2 format in a .ts file or in a Blu-ray compatible format .m2ts

qas.question: How doesn't the Personal Video Recorder store content?
Recent systems can record a broadcast SD program in what format?
What uncompressed storage option wasn't introduced in 2008?

context: The massive amount of data storage required to archive uncompressed streams meant that inexpensive uncompressed storage options were not available to the consumer. In <a0_0><b4_0>2008<b4_0/><a0_0/>, <a3_0>the <b7_0>Hauppauge 1212 Personal Video Recorder<b7_0/><a3_0/> was introduced. This device accepts HD content through component video inputs and stores the content <a1_0>in <b5_0>MPEG-2 format in a .ts file or in a Blu-ray compatible format .m2ts<b5_0/> file<a1_0/> on the hard drive or DVD burner of a computer connected to the PVR through a USB 2.0 interface. More recent systems are able to record a broadcast high definition program in its <a2_0>'<b6_0>as broadcast<b6_0/>' format or transcode to a format more compatible with Blu-ray<a2_0/>.
